frameDefinitions: This frame contains general locale words, and is mostly a place-holder in the hierarchy.
An Agent pauses in the course of an Activity. '' 'The government froze settlement construction in 1992 to facilitate peace talks.'
A Figure is located relative to a Ground location.
An Entity ends up with a particular new Final_quality.
Some entity (Theme) starts out in one place (Source) and ends up in some other place (Goal), having covered some space between the two (Path).
An Entity persists in a stable situation called a State
frameExamples: The government <t>froze</t> settlement construction in 1992 to facilitate peace talks.
That kite you see just to the right of his head was <t>moving</t> around pretty fast but the camera seemed to catch it ok.
listRoleDefinitions: A stable bounded area.  It is typically the designation of the nouns of Locale-derived frames.
This role identifies the <fen>Activity</fen> for which an <fen>Agent</fen> is pausing.
An <fen>Agent</fen> pauses in the course of an <fen>Activity</fen>.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> at which an <fen>Agent</fen> pauses in the course of an <fen>Activity</fen>.
This role identifies the <fen>Place</fen> where an <fen>Agent</fen> pauses in the course of an <fen>Activity</fen>.
The <fen>Ground</fen> serves as a basis for describing the location of the <fen>Figure</fen>.
The <fen>Figure</fen> is perceived as located relative to a certain <fen>Ground</fen> location. The figure can be an entity or an event.
The <fen>Figures</fen> are items which mutually serve to identify the location of the other items.
The region within which a <fen>Figure</fen> might be found.  This role is exclusive of <fen>Figure</fen>, and is a reconstrual that is not possible with verb lexical units.
The period of time during which the locative relation between <fen>Figure</fen> and <fen>Ground</fen> obtains.
The <fen>Entity</fen> which undergoes a change so that it possesses the <fen>Final_quality</fen>.
The quality that the <fen>Entity</fen> has at the end of the event.
When the change occurs.
Where the change takes place.
The <fen>Theme</fen> is the entity that changes location. Note that it is not necessarily a self-mover.
The <fen>Source</fen> is the location the <fen>Theme</fen> occupies initially before its change of location.
The <fen>Path</fen> refers to (a part of) the ground over which the <fen>Theme</fen> travels  or to a landmark by which the <fen>Theme</fen> travels.
The <fen>Goal</fen> is the location the <fen>Theme</fen> ends up in.
<fen>Area</fen> identifies the setting in which the <fen>Theme</fen>'s movement takes place without a specified <fen>Path</fen>.
<fen>Distance</fen> is any expression which characterizes the extent of the Motion.

This role is used for expressions that indicate motion along a line from the deitic center towards a reference point (which may be implicit) that is neither the <fen>Goal</fen> of the posture change nor a landmark along the way of the moving part of the body.  Often <fen>Direction</fen> is defined with reference to the canonical orientation of the Protagonist, or the orientation imposed by an implicit observer.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the Motion occurs.
The <fen>Place</fen> is the general area in which a specific motion (with <fen>Source</fen>, <fen>Path</fen>, or <fen>Goal</fen>) occurs.
Concrete or abstract entity
State of an Entity.
listRoleExamples: There used to be a forest in that area.
<fex><t>Next to</t> the kitchen</fex> is the best place to locate your garage .
The explosion made <fex>me</fex> move in a hurry.
The policeman moved <fex>away from the door</fex>.
Jo moved <fex>past Dad</fex> into the hall.
The car moved <fex>into the slow lane</fex>.
The twig floated atop the water <fex>for about 100 yards</fex>.
A radioactive cloud drifted across Britain <fex>after the fire at the Windscale nuclear factory</fex>.

sourceCandidateSpans.text: Shahdat of Maulana Qutbuddin Shahid R.A.
